body_html:
Thank you for your patient and detailed explanation. I will try it as you say. Thank you!!! At 2018-02-23 19:30:01, "clarklight" <notifications@github.com> wrote: For me anyway the jpeg looked like it was correct, the format looked correct. I checked everything,I even open it to view the image, everything looked right, but for some reason for me when the images is moved from a folder to another some transfer method causes jpeg to loss some bits from it's base64 string.......no idea why. When I compared the Actual base64 then I saw the string was slightly different.......then I tried a different transfer method, when the base64 string is 100% the same.....then it worked. No idea why, I think the Tensorflow has to mount the image into the image parser in C++ then read it, so basically the system couldn't mount the image to parse and gave that error, if you guys base64 is correct or file format is correct, maybe take a look at the log to see if the image is even getting read correctly.
On 23 Feb 2018 20:16, "clovking" ***@***.***> wrote: @clarklight <https://github.com/clarklight> , I meet a silimar question with you when i train models on google TensorFlow Object Detection API, May i ask if the question has been solved? what's the problem and how to solved? thank you! — You are receiving this because you were mentioned. body_text:
Thank you for your patient and detailed explanation. I will try it as you say. Thank you!!!







At 2018-02-23 19:30:01, "clarklight" <notifications@github.com> wrote:
For me anyway the jpeg looked like it was correct, the format looked
correct. I checked everything,I even open it to view the image, everything
looked right, but for some reason for me when the images is moved from a
folder to another some transfer method causes jpeg to loss some bits from
it's base64 string.......no idea why. When I compared the Actual base64
then I saw the string was slightly different.......then I tried a different
transfer method, when the base64 string is 100% the same.....then it
worked. No idea why, I think the Tensorflow has to mount the image into the
image parser in C++ then read it, so basically the system couldn't mount
the image to parse and gave that error, if you guys base64 is correct or
file format is correct, maybe take a look at the log to see if the image is
even getting read correctly.
On 23 Feb 2018 20:16, "clovking" ***@***.***> wrote:
 @clarklight <https://github.com/clarklight> , I meet a silimar question
 with you when i train models on google TensorFlow Object Detection API, May
 i ask if the question has been solved? what's the problem and how to
 solved? thank you!

 —

body:
Thank you for your patient and detailed explanation. I will try it as you say. Thank you!!!







At 2018-02-23 19:30:01, "clarklight" <notifications@github.com> wrote:
For me anyway the jpeg looked like it was correct, the format looked
correct. I checked everything,I even open it to view the image, everything
looked right, but for some reason for me when the images is moved from a
folder to another some transfer method causes jpeg to loss some bits from
it's base64 string.......no idea why. When I compared the Actual base64
then I saw the string was slightly different.......then I tried a different
transfer method, when the base64 string is 100% the same.....then it
worked. No idea why, I think the Tensorflow has to mount the image into the
image parser in C++ then read it, so basically the system couldn't mount
the image to parse and gave that error, if you guys base64 is correct or
file format is correct, maybe take a look at the log to see if the image is
even getting read correctly.
